import React from 'react'; import {Link} from "react-router-dom"; import ExternalLink from './ExternalLink'; import EnsembleImage from '../images/ensemble-project.png'; import TraneLogo from '../images/trane-logo.png'; import EnsembleInitialConcepts from '../images/ensemble-initial-concepts.jpg'; import EnsembleRefiningDesign from '../images/ensemble-refining-design.png'; import EnsembleRolesNew from '../images/ensemble-roles-new.PNG'; import EnsembleRolesOld from '../images/ensemble-roles-old.PNG'; import {ReactComponent as BinaryTexture} from '../images/binary-texture.svg'; function Project1() { return(

Project

01

Redesigning user permissions for Tracer® Ensemble®

5 min read  //  July 2020 - January 2021

My Role

Sole UX resource assigned to project. Responsible for all user research & design work

Project Team

2 Product Owners, Portfolio Manager, Product Planning Engineer, Software Developers

Tools I Used

Axure, Microsoft Teams, Confluence, PowerPoint, Miro, Cisco WebEx

The Redesign: Before and After

Background

Ensemble users care a lot about control. The primary purpose of the product is to give Building Operators and Facilities Managers a one-stop-shop to control and monitor their buildings. And there's a plethora of features that allow them to do just that.



They also care about controlling who has access to these features. Today, Ensemble addresses this need by allowing site administrators to assign roles to other users. These roles determine what permissions they have access to.



Customers had shared feedback that the current solution wasn't flexible enough. They wanted to be able to pick and choose the permissions each role had access to. I was brought in to design a more flexible workflow.

Identifying User Needs

I started the design process by figuring out what the users' needs were. I was new to the team, so I met with stakeholders to learn more about who the users are and why they use the product. Together, we identified three problems that we needed to address with the redesign:

Problem #1

Users can't setup permissions the way they want to.

Problem #2

Users don't understand our terminology.

Problem #3

The current permissions structure is hard to maintain.

Initial Concepts

Users wanted more control over permissions than the original design could provide. To fulfill this desire, I knew that I would have to redesign the workflow for setting up permissions. The challenge was finding a way to give users the flexibility that they wanted while also making it easy to for them to understand.



I started sketching some early concepts in my notebook (I always keep one within arm's reach) before moving to Axure to flesh out my ideas.

A senior UX Designer who was familiar with Ensemble provided early feedback and helped familiarize me with the Ensemble design patterns.

Customer Feedback

After putting together a prototype, I sought feedback from customers to determine if the design was suitable. I recruited individuals from a variety of market segments to ensure that my sample adequately represented our user base. I met with each individual virtually. I shared my screen while I asked them questions. The questions were designed to figure out users' preferences and to determine if they understood the design. The biggest takeaway from these sessions was that customers generally didn't know about the user management features we already had.

Quote #1

This is much better than how I do it today.

Quote #2

I didn't know this feature existed, but I like it.

Quote #3

The new workflow makes me confident that I'm going to get what I expect when I set up a new user.

Refining the Design

I used the research findings to improve my design. To help customers discover the feature, I renamed the permissions setup page and all links to the page from "User Roles" to "Roles" (we learned that users often confused User Roles with Users).



We learned that users typically give people the same level of access for all equipment, so I added an accelerator to account for this behavior.

Adding this option saved 11 clicks.

Usability Testing

With the time left before the project deadline, I conducted a usability test. I wanted to discover if there were any unforeseen usability issues before I handed off the design to the developers. I recruited three participants and wrote a task list for them to complete. The task list required them to perform user management tasks as they would in the real world.



While we didn't uncover any glaring design flaws during usability testing, we did observe that users spent more time trying to find permissions in the permissions wizard than we originally thought. My solution to this problem was to migrate the permissions wizard from a modal to a full page. I suspected that it would be easier for users to scan and find permissions if we displayed more permissions at a time.

Outcome

I created the final visual design by following our style guidelines and handed it off to the developers. At the time of me writing this, the design has not yet been implemented. We got a lot of positive feedback from customers throughout the design process, so I'm confident the feature will be well-received when it is released.

Thanks for reading!

); } export default Project1;
